title: Acid Rain and Its Environmental Impact
summary: An exploration of how acid-base chemistry drives the formation of acid rain and its devastating effects on ecosystems, buildings, and human health.
content:
Case Study: Acid Rain and Its Environmental Impact

Acid rain is a direct consequence of acid-base chemistry occurring in the atmosphere. When sulfur dioxide (SO₂) and nitrogen oxides (NOₓ) — released primarily from burning fossil fuels — react with water vapor, they form sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄) and nitric acid (HNO₃).

The Chemistry

The key reactions are:

  • SO₂ + H₂O → H₂SO₃ (sulfurous acid)
  • 2SO₂ + O₂ + 2H₂O → 2H₂SO₄ (sulfuric acid)
  • 4NO₂ + O₂ + 2H₂O → 4HNO₃ (nitric acid)

Normal rainwater has a pH of about 5.6 due to dissolved CO₂ forming carbonic acid. Acid rain can have a pH as low as 4.2 — roughly 25 times more acidic than normal rain.

Environmental Consequences

Acid rain leaches essential nutrients like calcium and magnesium from soils, weakening trees and reducing their resistance to disease. Lakes and rivers that receive acid rain suffer reduced biodiversity; many fish species cannot survive below pH 5. Marble and limestone structures — including historic monuments — dissolve when exposed to acidic precipitation through the reaction: CaCO₃ + H₂SO₄ → CaSO₄ + H₂O + CO₂.

Mitigation Strategies

Liming lakes (adding calcium carbonate) temporarily neutralizes acidity. Long-term solutions require reducing SO₂ and NOₓ emissions through cleaner fuels and catalytic converters. This case study illustrates how industrial acid-base chemistry has far-reaching environmental consequences.
